awd_titl_txt: A large-scale investigation into the foundations and development of social cognition
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (SBE) Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Laura Schulz at MIT and Dr. Elizabeth Bonawitz at Harvard, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist examining how children’s understanding of other minds develops. To share what we know, learn from others, work together, and conduct even simple conversations, we need to consider other people’s mental states—their goals, desires, knowledge, and beliefs. This social cognitive ability to figure out what other people are thinking, and reason about their mental states, matures throughout the preschool years. However, despite the importance of these capacities for teaching, learning, and basic communication, it is still not fully clear how they emerge. Instead, recent work has uncovered a puzzle: while preschoolers have an early grasp of mental states like goals, preferences and desires, they often struggle to reason about what others know or believe. 

To investigate how different aspects of mental state reasoning emerge, this project will leverage a computational approach to clarify the cognitive capacities required for different mental state reasoning tasks, and validate an updated mental state reasoning battery to assess the development of each capacity. The project will then leverage recent advances in large-scale online developmental science to administer this battery to a large and representative sample of children. Specifically, the NSF-funded online CRADLE infrastructure will enable the project to collect data of unprecedented richness and scale, collecting data from participants worldwide, and following participants longitudinally with ease. Through this project, the fellow will develop new tools and pipelines for online data collection, and will assess whether these new methods enable researchers to recruit more representative samples. These advances will be of broad use to the field of developmental science. By learning more about the development of human social cognition, we can better understand what makes humans such uniquely good teachers, learners, and communicators. This information can help researchers continue improving educational policy, help clinicians better assist individuals who struggle with mental state reasoning, and enable scientists to design artificial intelligences that can better interact with humans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Across the animal kingdom, humans are uniquely social: we rely on others to teach us more than we could ever discover on our own, pass on our knowledge in turn, and work together to accomplish things none of us could have done alone (sometimes, spanning many human lifetimes). These impressive capacities all rely on our basic ability to understand and reason about other minds, called a “Theory of Mind.” Our Theory of Mind allows us to figure out what others are thinking and feeling, and use that information to plan our own actions in complex social situations. 

 

For many years, developmental scientists have investigated the emergence of this understanding of other minds. Our naive intuitions about other minds are evident from early in childhood: even young children consider others’ wants and goals when figuring out how to help, judge others by considering if they harmed someone intentionally or accidentally, and consider what others know when teaching or learning. At the same time, big questions remain. 

 

On a broad point, like most psychology research, developmental research is run in-person, and therefore relies on families who live near universities and can afford admission to expensive museums or preschools where researchers recruit participants. Overall, participants tend to be upper-middle class and White. Psychology researchers, including developmental scientists, are now spending more time asking if results from narrow populations hold for the broader US and worldwide population. 

 

On a more specific point, there continue to be major debates in developmental science about how our Theory of Mind capacities develop. These include questions about whether increased exposure to reasoning about other minds makes a difference (for example, through siblings and parents), and whether capacities like self-control and reasoning about alternatives (which could help us understand that others think and want things different than we do) matter.

 

Recent advances in our field’s methods presented us with an opportunity to tackle these questions, while at the same time contributing to a broader NSF-funded project called “CRADLE”, where researchers at many universities have been working together to better understand early childhood development. Specifically, it is difficult to recruit large samples that represent the US population through traditional in-person recruitment methods, and it is even more difficult to get children to participate in multiple studies across time. Recent advances in online developmental science allowed us to sidestep these problems, posting studies online for families to participate in at their leisure. This allowed us to recruit a sample that better represents the US population, since participants can live anywhere and only need a phone or computer with a wifi connection, and it also allowed families to come back and participate in as many studies as they wanted to—allowing us to study how many different cognitive capacities are developing at the same time. 

 

By conducting this work, we help advance methods in developmental science, providing a clear guide for future researchers for how to conduct this kind of research, re-recruiting the same families many times. We contribute data about Theory of Mind development to the broader CRADLE project, so that researchers can study how different capacities assessed by CRADLE interrelate, going beyond most prior research. And finally, we advance knowledge about Theory of Mind development more specifically. 

 

In the funded project, we were able to replicate the scale most commonly used to measure Theory of Mind in-person (see Wellman & Liu, 2004). We showed that overall, translating the task into an online format did not change the scale’s results. In addition, inspired by computational models of Theory of Mind, we found that knowledge reasoning capacities (which past scales measure less richly), also seem to be important components of Theory of Mind development. We are also starting to be able to answer questions about the capacities and experiences that feed into Theory of Mind development, like self-control, reasoning about alternatives, and exposure to mental-state reasoning. Furthermore, this rich data can also allow us to validate and further develop computational models of Theory of Mind. Finally, by releasing our methods publicly and engaging in open science practices, we enable future researchers to easily build upon our work, accelerating progress in developmental science.
